name: Tutorial

text.value: Credit card dispute resolution: A Bonita case managment example

Welcome on this tutorial !
You'll get here an overview of this case management example, how it works, how to use it, and how to create your own case management application !
Enjoy the reading !
I- Purpose of the example

The purpose of this Credit card dispute resolution application is to provide a complete - well-designed case management example created with Bonita.
it is meant to illustrate the power of the Bonita platform to implement and execute case management based applications.
Using this example, you should be able to understand the main concepts to create a case management based Bonita application.
II- The case management event handler

The Bonita case management possibilities depends entirely on an Event Handler embedded in the Bonita Engine.
The event handler is triggered each time an activity is completed, and has the following effect:
All the transient data who the name starts with `$` are re-evaluated when the case management event handler is triggered.
Those transient data are meant to contain the activity state logic. Each activity is supposed to have its own transient data.
The value of a data should reflect the state of the associated activity (Required, Discretionary, Optional, Not Available), depending on the current state of the process (a given task has been completed, a given business data has been valuated ...).
When the event handler is triggered, the values of those data are re-evaluated, and so the state of each activity.
The state of each activity is displayed in the User Interface, and only available activities are executable. The logic behind that is computed in a REST API extension in this example.
The ACM event handler is already activated

Activate the case management event handler

By default, the case management event handler isn't activated. To activate it, the following argument has to be passed when launching the Tomcat:

-Dcom.bonitasoft.engine.plugin.acm.REGISTER_ACM_HANDLER=true

In the Bonita Studio, you can pass this argument to the engine tomcat by going to Preferences → Server settings → Tomcat JVM additional arguments. The parameter is present by default, you just have to set its value to true
III- Set up the example

In order to be able to use this example, there is a couple of artifacts to deploy.
All the artifacts can be deployed from the Bonita Studio using the Bonita project explorer: right click on an artifact -> deploy.
Artifacts to deploy:
  1. Business data model bom.xml
  2. Organization ACME.organization
  3. Processes Credit Card Dispute and Data initialization (ensure that the active environment is the environment development)
  4. Rest API extension creditCardDisputeResolutionRestAPI
  5. Application descriptor credit-card-dispute-resolution
IV- Data initialization

The credit card dispute resolution process requires some data to be executed:
  • An account contains all the transactions of a given customer
  • A dispute is started following the call of an existing customer who wants to dispute a transaction on its account
The database must be populated with some users, transactions and account before toi be able to start a dispute
Data created
Customers
V- Open the application and create a dispute

The database contains now the required data to start a case of the credit card dispute resolution process.

You can now {{mainAppsLink}}
The home page of the main application display the list of the opened disputes. This list should be empty if it's the first time you open the main application.

Only member of customer service can start a new credit card dispute.

Daniela Angelo is a member of customer service. If you are not already logged with Daniela Angelo , log out and log in with:
User name: daniela.angelo
Passeword: bpm

Once logged as a member of customer service, you should be able to create a new dispute by clicking on the new dispute button (top right corner).
A customer ID will be asked to start the dispute, you can pick one from the customer list above.
We simulate here a situation where a customer call the customer service to dispute a transaction, the customer service employee starts a new dispute case with the ID of the calling customer
The interface
The main interface of the dispute resolution is splitted in several parts:

On the left, you can see the task list. It contains all the available actions for the current user, and their state.
Each action corresponds to a task in the process Credit Card Dispute.
The state of a task can be Required Discretionary Optional N/A (not available) or Completed
On the process, you can see on each task a transient data named $activityState. Each data has the responsability to compute the state of its task (see the event handler section for more details).
Depending on its state, an action can be performed or not, by clicking on its name.
On the top right of the task list, there is a button Create Activity. It can be used to create an action that needs to be performed (send a mail to someone, call a client ...).
Once created, the new activity is available in the task list, and can be performed at any moment.
On the right, there is informations about the customer and the current dispute. Those informations are updated when actions are performed.

On the bottom, there is three panels: History, Comments and Documents
The history panel contains a summary of all the actions performed during the dispute resolution.
The comments panel contains all the comments added during the dispute resolution (report of a call with the customer...)
The documents panel contains all the documents added during the dispute resolution (Customer bill...)
VI- Gather dispute details

The first required action of the dispute resolution process is the gather dispute details action: the customer is on the phone with the customer service employee, and explain to him the issue.
Stay logged with Daniela Angelo, and click on the action Gather dispute details.

You have here the possibility to enter details about the dispute (according to what the customer on the phone is telling you), and then to reject or follow-up the dispute, depending on if you consider it valid or not.
The Merchant identification number (MIN) corresponds to the identifier of the merchant who performed the transaction the customer is disputing. if the customer doesn't know it, it can be retrieved later, during the dispute investigation.
For this tutorial enter an amount of 600 USD, a random date in the past, and follow-up the dispute.
VII- Investigate transaction

The next required action to perform is the action Investigate transaction. The customer gave details about the dispute during the first call, a dispute agent has now to investigate.

Joseph Hovell is a dispute agent. log out and log in with:
User name: joseph.hovell
Passeword: bpm

During the investigation, the dispute agent will, for exemple, find the Merchant Identification Number associated to the disputed transaction.
  • Perform the action Investigate transaction, add the following comment: MIN found using customer transaction date
  • Perform the action Update dispute and add a Merchant identification number (Exemple: 10-0002363)
The database has been populated with transactions, you can find the MIN of a transaction by looking into the account details, if you want to simulate a real investigation
VIII- Chargeback

After the investigation, the dispute agent decides to chargeback the customer.

Perform the action Update dispute, and set the status to PROCESSING CHARGEBACK

The action chargeback should still be unavailable, because the amount to chargeback is higher than the Review amount threshold (default value: 500) A dispute supervisor has to perform a review to authorize the chargeback.

Zachary Williamson is a dispute supervisor. log out and log in with:
User name: zachary.williamson
Passeword: bpm

Perform the action Review, with the following comment: Review done, chargeback authorized.
The dispute supervisor has also the possibility to change the review amount threshold, by performing the action Update parameters. If you set the threshold to a value higher than the amount to chargeback, then the review isn't required anymore.

Log in with Joseph Hovell, and perform the action Chargeback.
The customer has been charged back, you can now resolve the dispute by clicking on the resolve button.

mainAppsLink.value: return "open the main application";

description: Page generated with Bonita UI designer
